name: Silphium Honey Chicken
summary: Roasted chicken glazed with honey, pepper, and a silphium-inspired herb blend.

steps.instruction: Whisk honey, oil, vinegar, pepper, silphium mix, and salt into a glaze.
tutorialTips: Balance sweet and sharp before glazing.

steps.instruction: Coat chicken and roast at 400 F (200 C) for 30 minutes.
Brush with extra glaze and roast 10 more minutes until lacquered.

history.context: Inspired by Roman sweet-sour flavor profiles and the legendary silphium spice.

name: Garum Citrus Garden Salad
summary: A bright salad with citrus, herbs, and a garum-style vinaigrette.

steps.instruction: Whisk oil, garum-style sauce, and lemon juice.
tutorialTips: Add a splash of orange juice for sweetness.

steps.instruction: Toss greens, oranges, and mint with dressing.
Finish with toasted pine nuts.

history.context: Inspired by Roman use of citrus, herbs, and fish-based seasonings.

name: Spelt Porridge with Figs
summary: Warm spelt porridge enriched with figs, honey, and warm spices.

steps.instruction: Simmer spelt in water with salt until tender.
Stir in figs and cinnamon, cook 5 minutes.
Sweeten with honey and serve.
tutorialTips: Add a splash of warm milk if desired.

history.context: Puls (grain porridge) was a Roman staple; this is a sweetened version.

name: Herbed Olive and Anchovy Spread
summary: Savory olive spread with herbs and anchovy, inspired by garum flavors.

steps.instruction: Pulse olives, anchovy, herbs, and oil into a coarse paste.
Taste and adjust with oil or herbs.

history.context: Inspired by Roman olive preparations and fish-seasoned condiments.

name: Barley and Beet Hearth Stew
summary: Earthy barley stew with beets, leeks, and herbal oil.

steps.instruction: Sweat leek in olive oil until soft.
Add barley and beets; stir 2 minutes.
Pour in stock and simmer until barley is tender.
Finish with lovage and serve.

history.context: A rustic grain stew inspired by Roman rural cooking.

name: Cheese and Herb Hearth Cakes
summary: Pan-seared cheese cakes with herbs and honey drizzle.

steps.instruction: Mix ricotta, flour, egg, and herbs into a thick batter.
tutorialTips: If too loose, add a spoon of flour.

steps.instruction: Pan-sear spoonfuls until golden on both sides.
Drizzle with honey to serve.

history.context: Inspired by Roman libum and cheese-based offerings.

name: Lentil and Leek Pot
summary: Hearty lentils stewed with leeks, coriander, and vinegar.

steps.instruction: Sweat leek and garlic in olive oil.
Add lentils and coriander; cover with water and simmer.
Finish with vinegar and serve.

history.context: Lentils were common in Roman diets; vinegar brightens the dish.

name: Pistachio and Date Bites
summary: Sticky date confections with pistachio and rosewater.

steps.instruction: Warm dates with honey and salt, then mash.
tutorialTips: Use a splash of water if too dry.

steps.instruction: Fold in pistachios and rosewater.
Shape into small bites and chill.

history.context: Sweetmeats were popular in Roman banquets; this is a creative echo.

name: Pear and Spiced Wine Relish
summary: Pears simmered in spiced wine with honey and black pepper.

steps.instruction: Simmer pears in wine with honey and spices.
tutorialTips: Keep a gentle simmer to avoid mush.

steps.instruction: Reduce slightly and serve warm or cool.

history.context: Fruit cooked in wine appears in Roman culinary traditions.

name: Farro Dumplings with Herb Oil
summary: Soft dumplings made from farro flour, dressed in herb oil.

steps.instruction: Mix flour, salt, and water into a soft dough.
tutorialTips: Add a splash more water if dry.

steps.instruction: Shape into small dumplings and boil until they float.
Toss with olive oil, parsley, and garlic.

history.context: Inspired by Roman grain preparations and herb oils.

name: Saffron Scallops with Grape Must
summary: Seared scallops with saffron and a sweet-sour grape reduction.

steps.instruction: Reduce grape must with vinegar to a syrup.
Sear scallops in oil until golden.
tutorialTips: Do not move for the first 2 minutes.

steps.instruction: Finish with saffron and drizzle syrup.

history.context: Sweet-sour sauces and saffron were prized in Roman kitchens.

name: Honeyed Wine Custard
summary: Silky custard scented with wine, bay, and honey.

steps.instruction: Warm milk with bay leaf; remove leaf.
Whisk yolks, honey, and wine; temper with warm milk.
Cook gently until thickened.

history.context: Roman desserts often combined wine and honey.

name: Fig and Vinegar Chutney
summary: Sweet-sour fig relish with wine vinegar and pepper.

steps.instruction: Simmer figs with water, vinegar, honey, and pepper.
Cool and serve with cheese or meats.

history.context: Sweet-sour relishes echo Roman palate preferences.

name: Herb and Sea Salt Flatbread
summary: Thin flatbread with rosemary, thyme, and flaky salt.

steps.instruction: Mix flour, water, oil, and herbs into a dough.
Roll thin, sprinkle salt, and bake at 425 F (220 C).

history.context: Flatbreads with herbs were common in Roman kitchens.

name: Roasted Carrots with Cumin and Honey
summary: Carrots roasted with cumin, honey, and vinegar.

steps.instruction: Toss carrots with oil, honey, cumin, and vinegar.
Roast at 425 F (220 C) until caramelized.

history.context: Cumin and honey appear in Roman seasoning traditions.

name: Olive Oil Honey Cake
summary: Moist olive oil cake with honey and sesame.

steps.instruction: Whisk oil, honey, and eggs until glossy.
Fold in flour, pour into a pan, and bake at 350 F (175 C).
Finish with sesame.

history.context: Olive oil and honey were central to Greek sweets.

name: Lentils with Honeyed Herbs
summary: Lentil stew brightened with honey, oregano, and lemon.

steps.instruction: Saute onion in oil until translucent.
Add lentils and water; simmer until tender.
Stir in oregano, lemon, and honey.

history.context: Greek lentil dishes often used herbs and citrus.

name: Barley and Herb Salad
summary: Chewy barley with cucumber, herbs, and lemon oil.

steps.instruction: Toss barley with cucumber and herbs.
Dress with oil and lemon.

history.context: Barley was a common Greek grain; salads used fresh herbs.

name: Fig and Feta Plate
summary: Fresh figs with brined cheese, herbs, and honey.

steps.instruction: Arrange figs and feta on a plate.
Drizzle with oil, honey, and thyme.

history.context: Figs and brined cheeses were staples in Greek diets.

name: Garlic and Oregano Lamb Skewers
summary: Lamb skewers marinated with oregano, garlic, and wine.

steps.instruction: Marinate lamb with oil, wine, garlic, and oregano.
Skewer and grill until charred and juicy.

history.context: Greek grilling traditions centered on lamb and herbs.

name: Eggplant with Grape Must
summary: Roasted eggplant with sweet-sour grape must and herbs.

steps.instruction: Brush eggplant with oil and roast until tender.
Reduce grape must to a syrup.
Drizzle eggplant with syrup, salt, and mint.

history.context: Sweet-sour sauces were prized across the Aegean.

name: Sesame Honey Bites
summary: Toasted sesame and honey confections.

steps.instruction: Warm honey and stir in sesame seeds and salt.
Spread on parchment and cool.
tutorialTips: Score before fully set for easy pieces.

history.context: Sesame and honey sweets are mentioned in Greek festival fare.

name: Millet Porridge with Grapes
summary: Millet simmered with grapes, honey, and bay.

steps.instruction: Simmer millet with bay leaf until tender.
Stir in grapes and honey.

history.context: Millet was a common grain in northern Greek regions.

name: Wine-Poached Pears with Laurel
summary: Pears poached in red wine, honey, and laurel.

steps.instruction: Simmer pears in wine with honey and laurel.
Reduce liquid and serve pears with syrup.

history.context: Wine-poached fruits appear in Greek banquet traditions.

name: Chickpea and Olive Bake
summary: Baked chickpeas with olives, oregano, and garlic.

steps.instruction: Toss chickpeas with oil, garlic, olives, and oregano.
Bake at 400 F (200 C) until fragrant.

history.context: Chickpeas and olives were staples on Greek islands.
